The space between lines 21 and 22, near the right margin, includes two spiders (one large, one small), at least two insects of uncertain species with wings folded, a caterpillar, a snail, and a bird perched on a vine, facing up and with its mouth open and probably singing. The odd shapes above the large snail may be another bird.

A flock of at least five birds flies right of line 26. Further to the right is a large bird, perhaps an eagle, soaring upwards. Above and to the right of the bird is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle with four wings.
A snake is intertwined with the vine in the lower right corner of the plate. It faces left, with mouth open and forked tongue clearly pictured.
Two snakes appear in the lower margin. Both face left with mouths open. The tongue of the right-most snake is clearly pictured.
Several flames appear below and to the right of the last word ("Enitharmon") in line 6 of the text.
Two vines extend horizontally between lines 6 and 7 of the text. Both may bear slender leaves.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 7 of the text.
Two vines spring from the first letter of the first word in line 10 of the text.
A vine—or perhaps a worm—twists above "Leutha," line 10 of the text. A second vine extends horizontally above the last two words in the same line.

A vine with multiple branches and leaves wends its way through the margin right of lines 9-20 of the text. At least one flower, shaped like a Meadia, grows close to the right margin of the plate, right of line 10. Another such flower appears below and to the left of the first one, right of line 13.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 16 of the text.
A vine descends from the first letter of the first word in line 21, and a vine with two loops grows from the descender of the last letter of “thy” in this line.
A vine grows from the last letter of the final word of line 35.
A large vine with many loops extends between lines 21 and 22 of the text. Some tendrils, perhaps with leaves, descend in the right margin to line 27.
A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 23, and from the descender of the second letter of "my" in line 26.
A vine grows from the first letter of the first word in line 33.
The odd form right of lines 27-31 probably represents sky or the margins of clouds.
A vine or plant with leaves and several branches appears in the bottom margin and right of lines 29-38 of the text.

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew.
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul:
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Varcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round;
Thy golden wings are my delight, & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colourd bow delights upon thy wings;
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light;
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon. prince of the pearly dew,
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee crystal form,
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love,
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents:
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe:
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha, secret dwellers of dreamful caves,
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black.
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions.
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.

She ceas'd, for All were forth at sport beneath the solemn moonLine 33, as originally written, contained these words, "and all went forth to sport," which were changed in the copper to "for All were forth at sport."
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs,
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry.
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate.Line 36, as originally written, ended with "and the angel trumpet blew!" These five words were erased from the copper plate.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. She wears a gown and has long hair. We see her from behind; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left. The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a gowned woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her gown, and presumably her legs, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying. Lower left, on top of the steps, is a fluted and broken pillar.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of three figures may be a family of mother, father, and female child.

A nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the young girl whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is her father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. He carries the limp body of a woman over his right shoulder.

We see a young female child from behind. She wears a long gown. Her left arm is held by the nude male; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left.

The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a gowned woman—perhaps the child's mother. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her left arm and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her gown, and presumably her legs, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying.
The background of the design below the text is composed mostly of a sheet of flames.
Three stone steps, or two steps and a plinth, and a fluted and broken classical pillar appear in the lower left corner of the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains a good many vegetative motifs and animals. Three vines extend horizontally between lines 3 and 4. The vine on the left includes a loop and one ivy-like leaf. The next vine to the right bears two oak or grape leaves. The largest vine, furthest to the right, has long, slender leaves. At least four insects, perhaps beetles and one caterpillar, crawl on it. Three winged insects (some little more than dots) and one butterfly (below "fury" in line 3) fly above the vine. Below "of his" in line 3, a bird perches on the vine but spreads its wings as if about to fly into the air. An oak or grape leaf grows into the left margin from the first letter of the first word of line 4. A vine with ivy-like leaves extends horizontally between lines 9 and 10, divides into several branches in the right margin, and has one branch arching back to the left at line 7. A branch bearing five oak leaves and one acorn extends into the right margin following the final line of text. To the right of this branch, a bird flies upward on extended wings. A vine with two loops grows from the first letter of "FINIS" (line 13) and extends horizontally above the word.

A bird flies upward and to the left on extended wings near the right margin of the plate, right of the branch following the final line of text.

lg.l: Shot from the heights of Enitharmon,
And in the vineyards of red France appear'd the light of his fury.
The sun glow'd fiery red;
The furious terrors flew around!
On golden chariots raging, with red wheels dropping with blood;
The Lions lash their wrathful tails!
The Tigers couch upon the prey & suck the ruddy tide;
And Enitharmon groans & cries in anguish and dismay.
Then Los arose his head he reard in snaky thunders clad:
And with a cry that shook all nature to the utmost pole,
Call'd all his sons to the strife of blood.
